metadata.title: Development of titania-supported iridium catalysts with excellent low-temperature activities for the synthesis of benzimidazoles via hydrogen transfer

Development of titania-supported iridium catalysts with excellent low-temperature activities for the synthesis of benzimidazoles via hydrogen transfer Tatsuhiro Fukutake a Kenji Wada b ⁎ Han Yu a Saburo Hosokawa c d Qi Feng a a Department of Advanced Materials Science, Faculty of Engineering and Design, Kagawa University, Takamatsu 761-0396, Japan Department of Advanced Materials Science Faculty of Engineering and Design Kagawa University Takamatsu 761-0396 Japan b Department of Chemistry for Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, Kagawa University, 1750-1 Ikenobe, Miki-cho, Kita-gun, Kagawa 761-0793, Japan Department of Chemistry for Medicine Faculty of Medicine Kagawa University 1750-1 Ikenobe, Miki-cho, Kita-gun Kagawa 761-0793 Japan c Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, 1-30 Goryo-Ohara, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8245, Japan Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries (ESICB) Kyoto University 1-30 Goryo-Ohara, Nishikyo-ku Kyoto 615-8245 Japan d Department of Molecular Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Kyoto University, Kyotodaigaku Katsura, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8510, Japan Department of Molecular Engineering Graduate School of Engineering Kyoto University Kyotodaigaku Katsura, Nishikyo-ku Kyoto 615-8510 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Titania-supported iridium catalysts which enable the synthesis of benzimidazoles from 2-nitroaniline and primary alcohols under mild conditions have been developed. The iridium catalysts supported on {010}/{101}-faceted anatase (PA-135-3.5) showed the excellent activity in spite of their moderate surface areas, while there is a positive correlation between BET surface area and the activity of iridium catalysts. TEM analysis revealed the formation of small iridium nanoparticles (mean diameter; 1.0 nm) on PA-135-3.5, which would be one reason for the excellent catalytic activity. According to the XPS study, relatively high-valent iridium species would be responsible for the catalysis. Various primary alcohols bearing electron-withdrawing or electron-donating groups were applicable. The removal of the solid catalyst by the hot filtration completely stopped further progress of the reaction, indicating that the catalyst acted heterogeneously. The catalysts could be recycled, and there was no leaching of iridium species into the solution. Keywords Iridium Titania Surface crystalline structure Hydrogen transfer Benzimidazole 1 Introduction Benzimidazoles are important substances as pharmaceutical raw materials, and their antiviral, antifungal, antiulcer, antihypertensive, antihistaminic, and anticancer activities have been reported [1]. Therefore, besides conventional synthetic methods [2], highly efficient, environmentally-benign synthetic methods of benzimidazoles, such as the dehydrogenative synthesis of benzimidazoles from 1,2-phenylenediamines and primary alcohols, have been developed [3–5]. On the other hand, hydrogen transfer reactions have been applied for a wide range of organic transformations [6]. Several heteroaromatic compounds have been synthesized via hydrogen transfer in the presence of iron- [7], ruthenium- [8], and palladium-based homogeneous complex catalysts [9]. These homogeneous catalyses, however, have their inherent disadvantages such as difficulty of the separation, recovery and recycling of the used catalysts and the contamination of the product by heavy metallic species. Since a major part of these problems could be overcome by the use of solid catalysts, various supported catalysts for organic syntheses have been developed [10–12]. The authors have developed a series of ceria-supported ruthenium [11] and rhodium [12] catalysts which enable a wide range of highly atom-efficient organic transformations. Recently, the authors developed titania-supported iridium catalysts which realize the dehydrogenative synthesis of benzimidazoles from 1,2-phenylenediamines and primary alcohols at 100 to 120 °C [[4]]. Remarkably, crystalline structures of titania supports significantly affected the reactions, and rutile-supported catalysts showed excellent activity [4b]. On the other hand, several solid catalysts effective for the synthesis of heteroaromatic compounds via hydrogen transfer were reported [13–14]. In particular, benzimidazoles were successfully synthesized from 2-nitroanilines and primary alcohols in the presence of titania-supported gold catalysts [14a] and hydrotalcite-supported palladium catalysts [14b]. However, both catalysts require a high reaction temperature above 150 °C. Recently, a supported palladium catalyst was reported to act at 80 °C, but the addition of a stoichiometric amount of strong base was required [14c]. Therefore, the development of new solid catalysts that enable the title reactions under mild conditions without any additives is of great significance. Here, we found that iridium catalysts supported on titania, especially on {010}/{101}-faceted anatase, show excellent activity at 80 °C. Detailed characterization of the catalysts was performed, and effects of facets of the titania surfaces are discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General information All manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. Tris(acetylacetonato)iridium(III) (Ir(acac)3, C15H21O6Ir), mesitylene, xylenes, toluene (super dehydrated), tetrahydrofuran (THF), methanol, biphenyl, o-terphenyl, nitroanilines, and benzyl alcohols were delivered from Wako and used as received. JRC (Japan Reference Catalyst) titanias (JRC-TIO-4, 6, 7, 8, 9) were delivered by Catalysis Society of Japan. Other titanias G-1, F-1, F-1R, F-2, F-6, F-10) were delivered by Showa Denko Ceramics Co.Ltd. 2.2 Physical and analytical measurements The organic products were characterized by solution phase 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra recorded at room temperature at 600 MHz and150 MHz, respectively, by JEOL JNM-ECA600. The resulting mixtures of the catalytic runs were analyzed by a GC–MS (Shimadzu GC–MS Parvum 2; Zebron ZB-1 capillary column, i.d. 0.25 mm, length 30 m, at 50–250 °C) and a gas-liquid chromatography (Shimadzu GC-14A; Zebron ZB-1 capillary column, i.d. 0.25 mm, length 30 m, at 50–250 °C). The leaching of iridium species from the catalysts was investigated by ICP-AES (Thermo Scientific iCAP 6300 spectrometer). The resulting gas was analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC, Shimadzu GC8AlT, Porapak-Q, i.d. 3 mm, length 2 m, at 50 °C). Solid catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmittance electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen gas adsorption, CO adsorption, thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTA), wavelength-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (WDX), and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). XP spectra were recorded using an ULVAC-PHI 5500 M T system equipped with a hemispherical energy analyzer, as reported previously [4b]. Binding energies were referenced to the C 1s level of residual graphitic carbon [15]. TEM photographs were taken using JEOL JEM-3010 microscope. Procedures of nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements and CO adsorption study have been noted in the previous report [4b]. TG-DTA analyses were performed using RIGAKU TG8120 in a stream (20 cm3 min−1) of synthetic air. The compositions of supported iridium catalysts were confirmed by a wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Panalytical Axios system equipped with a 4 kW rhodium anode X-ray tube) of Kagawa Prefectural Industrial Technology Center. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were recorded at BL01B1 beamline at SPring-8. Ir L3-edge XAFS spectra were recorded in transmission mode with a Si(111) double-crystal monochromator. 2.3 Preparation of faceted anatase titania nanoparticles {010}/{101}-Faceted anatase nanocrystals were hydrothermally prepared from H+-form layered titanate H1.07Ti1.73O4(HTO) nanosheets with a lepidocrocite-like (γ–FeOOH) layered structure by the reported procedure [16]. The 40 cm3 of the PA (n-propylamine)–HTO nanosheet colloidal solution was adjusted to be pH 3.5 with a 3 M HCl solution. The colloidal solution was sealed in a 80 cm3 stainless steel vessel with a Teflon-liner and then hydrothermally reacted at 135 °C for 24 h. The resulting powder was washed with distilled water several times and dried using a freeze drier to give rhombic nanocrystals of anatase, which are further designated as PA-135-3.5 (BET surface area; 66 m2 g−1) [16c]. {010}/{001}-Faceted anatase sample was prepared at a high pH of 11.3 (PA-135-11.3). [111]-faceted anatase nanocrystals with mean particle sizes of 50 nm were prepared by hydrothermal treatment of a tri-titanate nanosheet solution as reported [16d] and designated as [111]-50(A) (noted as TMA-200-3.6 in ref. [16d], BET surface area 45 m2 g−1). XRD patterns of representative titanias used in the present study are shown in Fig. S1 of Supplementary data. XRD patterns of F-series titanias have been reported elsewhere [4b]. 2.4 Preparation of supported iridium catalysts Supported catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. To a solution of Ir(acac)3 (0.10 mmol as Ir) in 10 mL of methanol, 1.0 g of a support was added in air at room temperature. After impregnation, the sample was dried overnight in air at 80 °C. Unless otherwise noted, the resulting powder was calcined in air at 400 °C for 30 min in a box furnace (ramping rate 10 °C min−1). Ca. 600 mg of calcined powder was mounted in a quartz tube (o.d. 12 mm) and reduced in a H2 (1.9 vol.%)/Ar flow (40 cm3 min−1) at the prescribed temperature (ramping rate; 10 °C/min) for 30 min by the use of a conventional flow reactor to give a support iridium catalyst. After the reduction, the catalyst was passivated in an O2 (ca. 2%)/N2 flow (40 cm3 min−1) at 50 °C for 5 min (see Scheme S1 in Supplementary data). The loading level of iridium species on the thus-prepard catalysts was monitored by WDX. 2.5 General procedure for the catalytic runs All of the reactions were performed using hot stirrers equipped with cooling blocks to reflux the solution. A typical reaction procedure for the synthesis of 2-phenylbenzimidazole (3aa) is as follows: 2-nitroaniline (1a) (1.0 mmol), benzyl alcohol (2a) (4.0 mmol), and solvent (1.0 cm3) were added to a glass Schlenk tube (20 cm3) containing the reduced catalyst (0.010 mmol as Ir). The reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 18 h under an argon atmosphere. The solid catalyst was removed by passing the mixture through a 0.45 μm polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) filter (Millipore Millex LH), and the products were quantified by using biphenyl (ca. 50 mg) as an internal standard. For isolation of the products, the remaining solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was repeatedly washed with hexane followed by the re-crystallization. 2.6 Hot filtration tests A 20 cm3 Schlenk tube was charged with 1a (2.0 mmol), 2a (8.0 mmol), and a titania-supported iridium catalyst (0.020 mmol as Ir) in toluene (2.0 cm3) together with an internal standard (tetradecane, ca. 150 mg) under an argon atmosphere. After the reaction was allowed to proceed for 2 h and 30 min, the mixture was filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE syringe filter into another preheated Schlenk tube. The filtrate was stirred at 100 °C, and the yield of 3aa was followed by GLC. Results and discussion The initial survey of various supported catalysts for the synthesis of 2-phenylbenzimidazole 3aa from 2-nitroaniline 1a and benzyl alcohol 2a was operated at 140 °C for 18 h (see Table S1). At this temperature, an iridium catalyst supported on JRC-TIO-6 (see Experimental) showed the highest activity to give the desired product 3aa almost quantitatively. The formation of 1 equivalent of benzimidazole from 1a requires the dehydrogenation of two equivalent of primary alcohol. One equivalent of aldehyde would be incorporated in the product, benzimidazole (see Scheme 3), while one equivalent of benzaldehyde would remain in the reaction mixture. According to the optimization of the reaction temperature, the reaction was found to smoothly proceed at 80 °C in the presence of a titania-supported iridium catalyst. The activity of iridium catalysts supported on various types of titanias was compared for the reaction of 1a with 2a at 80 °C for 18 h (see Eq. (1) and Table 1 ). As previously reported [4b], a part of the iridium species on the catalyst might be lost during calcination of the catalysts. Therefore, in the following study, the activity was compared under the same molar amount of iridium species by adjusting the weight of the catalyst. Among examined, iridium catalysts supported on anatase of high specific surface areas (see below), namely JRC-TIO-7, -8 and -9, showed the excellent activity. (1) As shown in Fig. 1 , there are strong correlation between BET surface areas and the yields of 3aa at 80 °C for 18 h. Irrespective of the crystalline structure of the titania supports, the yield of 3aa simply increased with increasing surface area. On the other hand, there was no correlation between the yield of 3aa and the CO-uptake ability of the catalyst (Fig. S2). Note that completely different trends were shown in the dehydrogenative synthesis of benzimidazoles [4b]: The catalytic activity did not depend on the surface areas of the catalyst but depended on the CO-uptake ability. These results clearly indicate that suitable catalytically active species for two reactions are significantly different (see below). To overcome the limitation by the surface area, effects of the crystalline structure of the titania surface were examined. One of the authors has developed anatase nanocrystals with abundant in specific crystalline facets on the surface, such as {010}/{101}-faceted PA-135-3.5 [16c]. BET surface areas of PA-135-3.3 and PA-135-11.3 were 66 m2 g−1 and 29 m2 g−1, respectively. Other characterization data have been previously reported [16c]. While the iridium catalyst supported on PA-135-3.5 has a moderate BET surface area, it showed excellent activity for the title reaction (Table 2 , entry 1) comparable to that of Ir/JRC-TIO-7 catalyst (see Table 1, entry 3). As shown in Scheme 1 , PA-135-3.5 is composed of rhombic nanocrystals with the (010) facet together with side (101) and (−101) facets, implying that {010}- and/or {101}-facets of anatase are suitable surfaces. However, an iridium catalyst supported on the {010}/{001}-faceted anatase, PA-133-11.5, showed poor activity (Table 2, entry 2). As discussed below, the presence of (001)-facet with high surface energy (Scheme 1) would be one reason of the poor activity. The [111]-faceted anatase-supported catalyst was also not very effective. The exposed facet of anatase TiO2 depends on its morphology [17]. It is usually controlled by adjusting reaction conditions and precursor, thus achieve the exposure of specific crystal facet. JRC-TiO-7 is composed of irregular spherical nanoparticles, and all possible facets, rather than any specific ones, are considered to be exposed. The reaction conditions and preparation methods of the catalysts were further optimized for Ir/JRC-TIO-7 and Ir/PA-133-3.5 catalysts. Table 3 summarizes effects of the amount of benzyl alcohol 2a and the solvents for the reaction for 3 h. The use of up to seven equivalents of 2a did not significantly changed the yield of 3aa (entries 1–4), and the reaction using 1.0 mL of 2a without solvent gave 3aa in higher yield (entry 5), indicating that the use of a solvent is not essential. The reaction at a higher substrate-to-catalyst ratio (entry 6) at 120 °C completed within 18 h to selectively give 3aa in 95% yield. Among solvents examined, aromatic ones were suitable, whereas the use of DMF resulted in poor 3aa yield (entry 9). Effects of calcination temperature of the titania-supported catalysts prior to the pre-reduction at 500 °C were investigated (see Table 4 ). The Ir/JRC-TIO-7 and Ir/PA-135-3.5 catalysts prepared without calcination showed the highest activity: 3aa was given in the yields over 99% and 96%, respectively. However, calcination in air above 250 °C was indispensable to regenerate the activity of used catalysts as discussed below. The catalyst calcined at 250 °C showed slightly higher activity than that calcined at 400 °C (entry 5). Similar to the case with the dehydrogenative reactions [4], pre-reduction of the catalysts at above 500 °C was indispensable to show the significant activity (Table S2). Effects of the iridium loading level on JRC-TIO-7 were examined (Fig. S3). Basically, the yield of 3aa increased almost in proportion to the iridium loading level. This implies that the intrinsic activity of iridium catalyst is not affected by the loading level, whereas the Ir/TiO2 catalyst of ultra-low loading level was reported to show excellent activity or the synthesis of quinolines from nitroarenes and alcohols [13]. The present catalysts could be recycled without a significant loss of activity as shown in Scheme 2 and Table 5 , which is a major advantage of solid catalysts [4,10–12]. After the reaction at 80 °C for 18 h, the solid catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with THF. The resulting powder was calcined in air at 400 °C for 30 min followed by the reduction in a stream of 2%H2/Ar gas at 500 °C for 30 min and the passivation at 50 °C for 5 min (see Experimental). The thus-recovered Ir/JRC-TIO-7 and Ir/PA-133-3.5 showed almost the same activity to the fresh catalyst, indicating excellent recyclability of the present catalyst. On the other hand, when the catalysts reused without calcination gave 3aa in very low yield. TG-DTA measurement of the recovered Ir/JRC-TIO-7 catalysts after washing by THF and drying showed a significant exothermic weight loss at 250–320 °C probably due to the combustion of carbonaceous materials (Fig. S4). XPS analyses clearly showed the presence of a significant amount of carbonaceous deposits after washing by THF and drying (see Table S3), while calcination greatly reduced the amount of surface carbon. Therefore, removal of carbon deposit by the calcination is indispensable to recycle the catalyst. To investigate whether the reaction actually proceeds on the surface of the solid catalyst [18], the catalyst was removed by hot filtration after the reaction had been allowed to proceed for 2 h and 30 min or 2 h. As shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S5, the removal of the solid catalyst completely stopped the further progress of the reaction. Note that inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis indicated that iridium species were not leached into the filtrate after the catalytic run at 80 °C for 18 h. These results suggest that the present solid catalysts acted heterogeneously. The present catalysts were applicable for the reactions of 1a with various primary alcohols as shown in Table 6 . Benzyl alcohol bearing an electron-donating methyl substituent (2b, 4-methylbenzyl alcohol) or an electron-withdrawing chloro group (2d, 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol) proceeded smoothly to give 3ab or 3ad, respectively, while the reaction with p-methoxybenzyl alcohol (2c) gave the desired product in a moderate yield. Note that 0.9 mmol of 4-methylbenzaldehyde and 0.9 mmol of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde were detected after the reaction between of 1a with 2b and 2d, respectively. Remarkably, a simple aliphatic alcohol, but-1-ol (2e), was applicable, and 3ae was produced in 92% yield. The reaction between 2-nitroaniline (1a) and 2-pyridinemethanol (2f) at 120 °C for 18 h gave 2-(2-pyridyl)benzimidazole (3af) in 57% yield, while the reaction of 2-(2-furyl)-1H-benzimidazole (fuberidazole, 3 ag) from 1a and furfuryl alcohol (2 g) was slow even at the elevated temperature. The reaction of p-nitroaniline (1c) with 2a successfully gave corresponding diimine 4aa in an excellent yield together with a very small amounts of intractable byproducts in the presence of the Ir/TiO2 catalysts (Table S4). Among the catalysts examined, iridium supported on PA-135-3.5 showed the highest activity (Eq. (2)). (2) XP spectrum of Ir core level on JRC-TIO-7 and PA-133-3.5 were compared after the reduction at 500 °C for 30 min. As shown in Fig. S6, The XP spectra of these catalysts were similar: the ratio of Ir(0) to Ir(0) + Ir(IV) of Ir/JRC-TIO-7 and Ir/PA-133-3.5 were 0.72 and 0.73, respectively. To estimate the oxidation state of iridium species on JRC-TIO-7 during the reaction, XP spectrum of the recovered catalyst was recorded. The mixture after the reaction of 1a and 2a at 80 °C for 18 h was recovered and evacuated (less than 1 Torr) overnight at 50 °C. The resulting powder was mounted in a grove box (Korea Kiyon) with O2 and H2O level below 0.5 ppm and transferred to the vacuum chamber without contact with air and moisture. Fig. 3 shows the result: Note that the Ir 4f peaks were overlapped with a Ti 3 s band. The ratio of Ir0 to Ir0 + IrIV was estimated to be 0.34, suggesting that relatively high-valent iridium species would be predominant during the catalytic runs and would be responsible for the catalysis. Similar trend was also observed for the recovered Ir/PA-133-3.5 catalyst (Fig. S7, The ratio of Ir0 to Ir0 + IrIV was estimated to be 0.55). Fig. 4 shows TEM images of the selected Ir/TiO2 catalysts after the reduction at 500 °C. As shown in Table S5, mean diameters of surface iridium species decreased in the following order, PA-135-11.3 > JRC-TIO-6 > PA-135-3.5 > JRC-TIO-7. The yield of 3aa increased in this order, indicating that smaller iridium particles show much higher catalytic activity. The use of high surface area titania supports were obviously advantageous for the formation of dispersed surface iridium species. On the other hand, uneven loading of noble metallic species on anatase was reported [4b,19], which would be due to differences in the surface energies between facets of anatase: Surface energies were reported to decrease in the following order, the {111} surface (1.61 J/m2) >{001} (0.95 J/m2) > {010} (0.57 J/m2) > {101} (0.43 J/m2) [20]. In the present study, PA-135-3.5 bearing {010}- and {101}-facets acted as an excellent support in spite of its moderate surface area. Therefore, these low-tension facets would be suitable for the formation of highly-dispersed iridium particles. Remarkably, large iridium particles were unevenly loaded on PA-135-11.3 (Fig. 4c). This could be caused by the presence of {001}-facet: Iridium complex would predominantly adsorb on such high-tension facets during the catalyst preparation procedure, which would result in the formation of large iridium particles. Detailed study on the effects of these facets is now in progress and will be reported in due course. Effects of calcination on the state of iridium species were investigated by the XANES spectra. Fig. S8 shows Ir L3-edge XANES spectra of reduced iridium catalysts supported on JRC-TIO-7 prepared (a) without and (b) with calcination at 400 °C for 30 min. Spectra of (c) Ir metal and (d) IrO2 are also shown for reference. Basically, the XANES spectra of the samples (a) and (b) are almost identical, and seem to be expressed by linear combination fitting of XANES spectra of iridium metal and oxide. However, slight difference in the white line intensity at around 11215 eV suggests a slightly greater ratio of metallic species in the catalyst (a) prepared without calcination [21]. Calcination could influence the oxidation state of iridium species of the reduced catalysts and the catalytic activity, probably by enhancing the interaction between iridium species and titania surface. One possible reaction mechanism is shown in Scheme 3 . The reaction would be initiated by the dehydrogenative oxidation of alcohol to form a corresponding aldehyde and iridium hydride species. The successive reaction via the formation of an imine intermediate bearing a nitro group (path A) or via 1,2-phenylenediamine (path B) would proceed. Unfortunately, experimental evidences for the reaction route have not been obtained yet, since these intermediates could not be detected by GC analyses. Further dehydrogenation of o-amino-substituted N-benzylideneaniline by iridium species would give 2-phenylbenzimidazole. Hydrogen gas was not detected at all by the GC analysis, indicating the relevance of the hydrogen transfer mechanism. For the dehydrogenative synthesis of azoles, the dehydrogenation of alcohols has been reported to be the slow step [5d,f]. For these processes, highly reduced zero-valent metal nanoparticle catalysts are generally used [22]. Therefore, the catalysts with well-reduced iridium species, which can uptake CO, would show the excellent catalytic activity for the dehydrogenative reactions. On the other hand, in the present reactions, hydrogen atoms abstracted from primary alcohol would be utilized for the reduction of nitro groups without the formation of molecular hydrogen. The XPS study suggests that relatively high-valent iridium species, which would not show high CO uptake ability, would be responsible (see Fig. 3). This would be one reason for the lack of correlation between the activity and the CO-uptake ability. 3 Conclusion Recyclable titania-supported iridium catalysts that enable the selective synthesis of benzimidazoles from primary alcohols and 2-nitroaniline at 80 °C were developed. In particular, iridium catalysts supported on {010}/{101}-faceted anatase showed the unexpected excellent activity, while the catalysts supported on high surface area anatase also showed high activity. The catalysts were recyclable, and the leaching of iridium species was not observed. According to the detailed characterization of the catalysts, the formation of highly-dispersed iridium species of around 1 nm in diameter would be favorable to show the excellent activity. Especially, in spite of the moderate surface area, highly dispersed iridium species were predominantly formed on the low surface energy {010}- and {101}-facets. The XPS study suggested that these iridium species were transformed to relatively high-valent iridium species, which would be responsible for the catalysis. Further application of the present catalysts for a variety of organic transformations via hydrogen transfer, including those for the utilization of renewable resources, is now in progress. coredata.dc:description: Titania-supported iridium catalysts which enable the synthesis of benzimidazoles from 2-nitroaniline and primary alcohols under mild conditions have been developed. The iridium catalysts supported on {010}/{101}-faceted anatase (PA-135-3.5) showed the excellent activity in spite of their moderate surface areas, while there is a positive correlation between BET surface area and the activity of iridium catalysts. TEM analysis revealed the formation of small iridium nanoparticles (mean diameter; 1.0 nm) on PA-135-3.5, which would be one reason for the excellent catalytic activity. According to the XPS study, relatively high-valent iridium species would be responsible for the catalysis. Various primary alcohols bearing electron-withdrawing or electron-donating groups were applicable. The removal of the solid catalyst by the hot filtration completely stopped further progress of the reaction, indicating that the catalyst acted heterogeneously. The catalysts could be recycled, and there was no leaching of iridium species into the solution.
coredata.dc:title: Development of titania-supported iridium catalysts with excellent low-temperature activities for the synthesis of benzimidazoles via hydrogen transfer
